Echo Class Reference

static EchoProperties calculateEcho (float volume, vector< float > boxValues, vector< vector< float >> boxPositions, float soundPosition[3], float distanceScale, float reflectionScale)

Detailed Description

The class which can do an calculation to find out the properties of an echo.

Author:
Alexander Nordh

Member Function Documentation

EchoProperties Echo::calculateEcho ( float  volume,
vector< float >  boxValues,
vector< vector< float >>  boxPositions,
float  soundPosition[3],
float  distanceScale,
float  reflectionScale 
) [static]

The calcualtion method, which does the echo calculation. It can be called statically and returns an EchoProperties object which describes the echo.

Parameters:
volume - The volume of the sound.
boxValues - The reflection values of the objects reflecting sounds in order to create the echo.
boxPositions - The positions of the objects reflecting sounds in order to create the echo.
soundPositions - The position of the sound source, listed as x, then y, then z in the array.
distanceScale - The higher this scale is, the faster the sound reduces due to distance, and the longer time it will take for the sound to return after being made.
reflectionScale - The higher reflection scale, the higher is the sound of the reflection.
Returns:
An EchoProperties object which contains the echo's volume, the delay before it should be played and if it should be played.

The calculateEcho method for calculating the echo's properties.

< A boolean to tell if the echo should be played at all.

< The delay before the echo should return.

< A variable keeping the total reflecting value (The sum of reflection values)

< A distance vector used to calculate the distance between the sound source and different objects.

< A distance variable used to calculate what objects to keep in the calculations and which to ignore.

< A list of all the distances from the sound source to the objects

The approximate reflection distance. An approximation of where the sound has bounced to reduce the volume and set the delay appropriately.

< The weights for each reflecting object used to calculate the aRD

< Save the start volume in sVolume variable
